Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: My phone buzzes just as I’m about to log in to the online petition site. It’s Jamie, frantic—she’s halfway to the airport and thinks she left her passport on her kitchen table. “Can you check and bring it if it’s there? I’ll miss my flight otherwise,” she pleads. I glance at the clock. The petition deadline is in ten minutes, and I’ve spent weeks rallying people to sign. My signature, as the local organizer, is expected—my absence would be noticed, maybe even questioned. But Jamie is my oldest friend, and she’s counting on me to come through in her emergency. My heart pounds as I picture her panicking at the airport, and at the same time, I imagine the petition going out without my name, my commitment to the cause suddenly in doubt. I stand frozen in my hallway, keys in one hand, laptop open on the table, torn between the urgent needs of a friend and the pressing demands of my activism.
